3.09.text: Dr Lucassen: Kia ora, good morning, I’ll just adjust this a little, being on the taller side.

9.11.text:
As you know my name’s Mathijs Lucassen.
I felt quite...

14.02.text: the previous two talks have been great, it’s really wonderful for me in terms of coming to meet...

20.10.text: see a group of people who are so interested in the things that I’m also interested in.

26.19.text: And when Alice was talking a bit about her experiences and her sort of passion, I guess,

31.79.text: and reasons behind why she was involved in this field...

36.42.text: I wasn’t going to talk about this but I felt inspired to just mention a little

41.14.text: in terms of my own personal experience as to why I’m here today really.

47.02.text: Back in 1996 I was a bit younger, and an undergrad university student down in Dunedin

54.70.text: and was coming out, and... which was a challenging time for me.

60.86.text: It was very useful to go to an icebreakers group and I found that really beneficial,

67.74.text: but unfortunately in the course of the year that I was there,

71.39.text: two of the young people that were in my group completed suicide,

75.15.text: so I think that had... well it had a massive impact

80.33.text: and has been my real motivation to work with young people with mental health challenges since,

87.46.text: and more recently, in a research role.

91.75.text:
So it’s just a bit of my background in terms
of why I’m so into

98.62.text: Well I should probably put on my presentation.

119.78.text:
So in terms of an overview of what I’m going
to be talking about this morning,

124.07.text: first I was going to start about definitions,

126.10.text: and already we’ve had a little bit of a chat about definitions and how they are fraught.

132.77.text: Then I’m going to talk a bit about suicide in young people generally, what we know about that,

138.31.text: and then suicide in LGBTTI young people more specifically,

143.01.text: and then I’m going to talk about two research projects that I’ve been involved with

148.03.text: and that they’re related to the field of suicide and queer, or LGBTTI, young people.

160.76.text: In terms of definitions, suicide, when we talk about... when I’m talking about suicide,

166.48.text: suicidal ideation, I’m meaning as reference to thoughts of harming or killing oneself,

172.31.text: attempted suicide is a non-fatal, self-inflicted destructive act with an explicit or inferred intent to die,

178.95.text: and suicide or completed suicide is a fatal self-inflicted destructive act with explicit or inferred intent to die.

185.48.text: So when we talk about suicidality, it’s a combination of those three terms or concepts.

192.80.text:
Some of you are probably thinking oh this
seems perfectly logical

196.05.text: and wouldn’t need to be defined, but I guess in terms of this stuff, in the research

202.19.text: around deliberate self-harm, there are some tensions in terms of where deliberate self-harm ends

209.19.text: and suicidal ideations begin, and generally the idea is around intent or intentions,

216.30.text: but we don’t always know what they are so that can make it a challenging field to research.

225.83.text: Then I’ve got this next slide, it’s definitions, LGBTTI young people.

231.69.text: There’s a picture there, and I ask this question is this young person...

236.17.text: and then a range of terms. Sort of somewhat a rhetorical question, because you can’t tell from a picture.

247.05.text: Again I just wanted to highlight that, because you’ll get lay-people who would say...

251.72.text: people outside of the community who would say oh I can tell,

254.42.text: show me a picture and I can tell you who they are and what they are,

256.90.text:
and I would challenge that because you
can’t do that.

262.60.text:
With the terms here that we’re talking about
today:

265.26.text: lesbian, gay, takatāpui, bisexual, trans, that’s the abbreviation, LGBTTI,

274.38.text: and we can talk about those terms in terms of both sexual identity and gender identity,

281.66.text: so intersex and trans, sometimes takatāpui also, can be categorised as being gender or gender identity,

290.96.text: and we can think about the others being sexual identity.

295.55.text: It’s just a fraught area, the language is really challenging,

299.50.text: and in young people, it’s also developmentally quite a challenge

305.29.text: because young people might not identify with any of the terms

310.22.text: that I’ve got there on the left-hand side because they might not like the political connotations,

317.26.text: because they’re still making sense of their own sexuality and gender,

321.59.text: so it’s important when we’re thinking about young people to be sort of aware of that developmental context.

330.90.text: Rightly or wrongly, in the Youth 2000 survey series we talk about sexual attraction,

337.68.text: and there are pros and cons to that.

341.40.text:
I guess the main advantage is that in a systematic lit
review of population-based surveys

348.73.text: that Professor Elizabeth Saewyc did in the University of British Colombia,

353.26.text: she found that if you survey young people and ask them about their sexual orientation

359.74.text: they have a preference for questions around sexual behaviour or same-sex sexual behaviour

363.67.text: and sexual attraction over the sexual identity labels,

367.90.text: so we’ve gone for the sexual attraction stuff in a lot of the work that I’ve been doing.

374.53.text: Another one I know, I’ve heard the term today already, rainbow community,

378.36.text: one that you might see a bit in the literature is sexual minority or gender minority,

383.75.text: they tend to be terms I’ve actually never heard anyone talk about themselves

388.28.text: as being a gender or a sexual minority, I don’t generally do that myself,

391.86.text: but it’s quite useful in the academic world I guess as a term as well,

397.05.text: so sometimes that’s a phrase that you can hear heard.

404.54.text:
So in terms of suicide and young people generally
I’ve got here a figure,

414.50.text: and unfortunately New Zealand is at the top of this figure.

419.38.text: It’s not something we want to be the top of the world in, or the top of the developed world I should say,

423.87.text: but this is trends in youth suicide rates per 100,000 people aged between 15 and 19 years,

431.17.text:
and you will see this is trends from approximately
1990 all the way through to about 2010.

438.26.text:
There is a sort of glimmer of hope there in
terms of those rates dropping over time,

445.02.text: but if we look at ourselves relative to the OECD average,

448.49.text: which is that middle light-blue trend line, you’ll see that we’re way above the OECD trend,

455.11.text: and really we should be aspiring to be more like Italy

458.11.text: which is there with the red line at the bottom.

460.94.text:
Other English speaking countries that are
similar to ourselves in many ways,

464.63.text: we’ve got the US and Australia slightly above that trend line, and the UK below it.

473.01.text: So youth suicide is an issue in New Zealand.

477.54.text: And the risk factors for youth suicide, there are several of these,

482.38.text: one is increasing age – the older the young person is the more likely they are to complete suicide.

489.64.text: A couple of reasons for that: one is, I guess, increasing cognitive ability

495.38.text: which means more sort of skill which is sad, but more skill in terms of planning out suicide,

504.56.text: and also less parental and other adult supervision.

508.67.text: Male sex – males have higher rates of completed suicide,

513.86.text: that’s predominantly because of methods used.

518.11.text:
Ethnicity – minority ethnic groups are thought to
be at an increased risk.

525.15.text: The research is saying this is mostly, or entirely linked to the disconnect for some people.

534.55.text: So for some people that are disconnected from their cultural heritage that places them at greater risk.

541.67.text:
I guess the parallel to that in terms of the
stuff around sexuality is what we’ve already...

546.53.text: sort of people have mentioned in terms of being disconnected,

550.20.text: or perhaps having real challenges, being excluded, not having support.

556.36.text: There’s probably a parallel there for ethnicity

559.05.text: for people that are excluded from their culture of origin that makes things harder for them.

565.88.text: Severe and frequent suicidal ideation – that seems very logical.

569.72.text: Previous attempt and the lethality of the suicide  attempt, so that’s the method used.

579.62.text: Interpersonal conflict or loss is another risk factor,

583.05.text: so if you think about family discord, relationship break-ups,

587.56.text: those are often factors involved in youth suicide.

591.92.text:
Mental ill health and things like depression, psychosis,
substance misuse disorders, maltreatment,

602.88.text: and exposure to suicide, so that’s friends and family that have completed suicide.

608.01.text:
The good news is there’s protective factors
as well, so sound mental and emotional wellbeing,

613.10.text:
good social skills, skills in relation to
managing your problems,

619.14.text: positive engagement with schools, and family cohesion.

630.17.text: Moira’s already mentioned a bit about the Youth ’07 study,

633.64.text: and I’ve got the book, the little image there,

638.53.text: and also a map of New Zealand, you know, in case any of you don’t know what New Zealand looks like.

643.69.text:
But that’s to sort of highlight that it’s a survey
that’s nationally representative,

648.38.text: and that’s very useful, because in terms of information about depression and suicide

654.85.text: there are only two other countries that have nationally representative data like this –

658.78.text: Norway and the United States – so it’s very unique.

662.14.text: I mean the counter-response from countries like Australia or Canada is that they’re much bigger than us,

667.86.text: so that’s why it’s easy for us to have nationally representative data,

672.85.text: but we can say well, it’s because we’re really efficient.

675.83.text: So I guess we get this sort of international competitiveness about these sorts of surveys.

681.07.text: And the Youth 2007 is the most recent with published results,

686.47.text: but as Moira mentioned we’ve got 2012 and we’re working on results for that,

690.64.text: and there’s the item in terms of transgender young people.

699.59.text: The orange hasn’t turned out on my little pie-chart there,

703.50.text: but that sort of greyish area is supposed to be orange for opposite-sex attracted.

709.07.text: We had about 92 percent of secondary school students in New Zealand in 2007

713.86.text: who identified as being opposite-sex attracted.

716.66.text: About six percent can be classified as sexual minority,

719.90.text: so that’s attracted to the same sex, both sexes, or not sure of their sexual attractions,

725.42.text: and about two percent are neither sex attracted.

727.90.text: With increasing age, that group that are not sure or neither, so the students that are older in the survey,

736.94.text: are less likely to respond to say that they’re not sure or neither.

742.37.text: Dr Lucassen: Oh, very good question, they’re twelve to nineteen years old,

745.01.text: so secondary school students in New Zealand, representative of that group.

750.71.text: I always say secondary school students, because that means

754.09.text: that they’re probably a slightly healthier population than young people overall,

759.58.text: because you... by doing a survey in a school you’re excluding the young people that aren’t at school,

764.93.text: so the kids that are sick on the day, or the kids, say, for example, in our community

769.64.text: that are having such a hideous time at school they just don’t go to school,

773.25.text: those that have been excluded and so-forth, so this is...

777.70.text: the sad thing about this is this is probably a slightly positive picture.

782.77.text: It’s probably, in reality, is that for an overall youth data is not that good.

792.03.text:
Also the Christchurch Health and Development
Study, the way in which they...

796.93.text: they have 2.8 percent that they have classified as being LGB,

801.93.text: and that’s actually not that dissimilar to looking at the sexual attraction question,

807.59.text: so it’s about three percent versus four percent.

811.41.text: The way in which the Christchurch Health and Development Study conceptualised this

816.49.text: is that they asked participants, when they were younger, what their sexual identity was,

822.00.text: so are you heterosexual, lesbian, gay, bisexual, and so forth,

826.72.text: and then they classified them as LGB,

829.63.text: and if you’d had a same-sex sexual partner from sixteen onwards then you’re also classified as LGB,

837.09.text: so it’s a combination of sexual identity and sexual behaviour.

841.50.text: And this study, just, I guess, acknowledgement to them,

844.54.text: that that was really quite ground-breaking at the time because it was a population-based study.

851.94.text: They asked the question and they looked at rates in terms of mental wellbeing.

857.83.text: These young people now are not very young, they’re thirty-six or thereabouts,

862.66.text: so it’s useful data in terms of youth mental health more now historically,

874.02.text: So most of the sexual minority youth were not suicidal

876.73.text: and didn’t have significant depressive symptoms, and that’s what Moira’s already said,

880.07.text: and I like highlighting that because it’s a positive message to be putting out there,

887.77.text: and we’re part of a vibrant, dynamic and great group,

890.66.text: and these young people are going to be an asset to New Zealand. They already are.

898.23.text: I’ve got here a couple of tables from a paper that we’ve published in the

901.23.text: Australian and New Zealand Journal of Psychiatry,

902.90.text:
which goes into a bit more detail from that Youth ’07
report,

906.14.text: and you’ll see there ‘current depressive symptoms',

908.51.text: that was measured with the Reynolds Adolescent Depression Scale short form,

912.71.text: so current depressive symptoms, opposite sex, we have the number there

916.66.text: – the N is 687 young people, or secondary school students,

920.93.text: and about ten percent who had current depressive symptoms.

925.62.text: I made the call of splitting them up – there are challenges in that,

928.99.text: but I guess for this paper it was interesting to do this and very useful,

934.60.text: so the rates for the ones that are same-sex attracted, both sex attracted, and not sure,

940.07.text: are considerably elevated, between twenty-two percent and thirty-two percent.

946.45.text: And then you’ll see in the next column I’ve got a little dotty box

950.77.text: around the odds ratios with the confidence intervals.

953.81.text: That’s basically a way in which we can control for certain variables,

957.90.text: and in this we controlled for ethnicity, age, sex, and level of economic... socio-economic deprivation.

968.26.text: And once we control for those variables, we’ve still got more than double

973.01.text:
the odds of depressive symptoms in the sexual
minority youth.

978.20.text:
The story is similar, but actually worse in
terms of attempted suicide.

984.07.text: That’s attempted suicide in the previous twelve months,

986.66.text: and you will see there four percent, or thereabouts, for the opposite-sex attracted young people,

990.87.text: and then much greater proportions for the same sex, both sex attracted, and not sure,

997.93.text: with seven times the odds for the both sex attracted young people.

1002.92.text: And what I might get you to do is I’ll...

1005.14.text:
if you’ve got questions, because sometimes
once I show these slides of these numbers

1008.71.text:
people are like ‘hmm, I want to know a bit
more about why this is’,

1011.36.text: just make a jot of those questions and I’ll try and whisk through the results

1015.01.text: and then we can have all the questions at the end if that’s ok.

1020.29.text: Deliberate self-harm, also a similar story, twenty percent of the opposite sex attracted young people,

1025.71.text: or 19.4 percent,  had deliberately self-harmed, and these...

1031.76.text: the proportion was much greater in the sexual minority youth, or same, both sex attracted, not sure group.

1040.42.text:
In terms of how this compares to the Christchurch
Health and Development Study,

1045.21.text: slightly different questions in that major depression...

1048.78.text: any major depression between 14 to 21 years of age

1052.38.text: – again you’ve got greater proportions because it’s depressive symptoms over a longer period of time,

1058.66.text: but if you look at the odds ratio, very similar story.

1062.50.text:
And ever attempted suicide, again, a very similar story
in terms of elevated risk.

1070.37.text:
And these bits of research I think are very
useful in terms of making an argument for

1076.66.text: elevated risk in the young people that are LGB.

1081.91.text: For the intersex and transgender young people, we don’t have that information yet,

1087.79.text: and we will hopefully have that for Youth ’12 coming up soon.

1094.62.text: For the young people that weren’t exclusively opposite sex attracted,

1097.67.text: we also found that they had increased difficulty getting help for emotional worries.

1102.76.text: This was quite important for the work I was doing for my PhD thesis

1106.58.text:
in terms of arguing a case for why computerised
therapy would be really useful.

1114.38.text: So why do we think LGBTTI youth are at increased risk?

1121.45.text: The research is suggesting it’s because of increased rates of bullying and victimisation,

1125.67.text: family rejection, substance abuse, and rates of... increased rates of mood disorders.

1131.57.text: I completely agree, but from a sort of quantitative research paradigm, or background,

1139.82.text: it’s... we are getting there in terms of having the evidence to really back that up,

1146.37.text: because there isn’t that much quantitative data to support that causal link.

1152.80.text: It’s there but it’s an emerging field, so we could still have more robust data.

1160.05.text: I guess researchers always want more robust data,

1162.85.text: but it’s definitely, I think, a field that is extending and expanding from now on.

1173.90.text:
So I’m briefly going to talk about two research
projects that I’ve been involved in –

1177.85.text: Rainbow SPARX, which is an intervention to help young people with depressive symptoms,

1184.08.text: and then Rainbow Youth’s education package in schools,

1187.25.text: and a formal evaluation that I’ve been involved with.

1194.45.text: So SPARX... this is an image from SPARX. You get to ride Te Hokioi, it's this giant eagle,

1201.02.text: and you go through seven different levels.

1203.37.text: It’s a computerised form of self-help based on principles of cognitive behavioural therapy,

1209.52.text: and a young person can do this at home,

1214.05.text: they can do it in the privacy of their own home at a time that suits them.

1219.43.text: And I was part of a team led by Associate Professor Sally Merry who worked on the SPARX project.

1226.68.text: And in fact in this room there are people that were involved in this project,

1230.97.text: and people will have known about this project, and me going on about it since 2008,

1236.45.text: Mark Henrickson who was an advisor on my PhD project,

1241.20.text: Thomas Hamilton who was very instrumental in terms of recruitment and influencing what I did with the project,

1248.53.text: and Rawiri Wharemate, who introduced us all and set the scene for the morning is our kaumātua at the Werry Centre,

1255.58.text:
so he was involved as well, so... and there
are loads of other people that I just wanted

1260.05.text: to acknowledge being involved in this project.

1264.43.text: What I started out doing was looking at whether or not

1267.70.text: something like this computerised form of therapy could help LGBTTI young people,

1274.61.text: and so... because I thought computerised therapy has real potential.

1279.56.text: Growing up from a Dutch sort of migrant farming background in rural New Zealand

1285.65.text: I knew that you can’t necessarily access culturally appropriate therapy

1291.94.text: outside of some of the major centres in New Zealand,

1294.41.text:
so I thought that was a real strength of computerised
therapy for our community,

1299.09.text: and the other is that it can be done in private when it suits a young person.

1303.28.text:
So the studies basically were pitched around
developing the resource and then evaluating it,

1310.40.text: and I had mixed methods in terms of the evaluation, both quantitative and qualitative results.

1317.29.text: And this is one of the characters with a sad face on.

1322.93.text: This was in the 2008 development stage, I did a series of focus groups

1330.94.text: and asked young people, LGB young people what they thought about prototypes of SPARX,

1337.98.text: and what sort of content they thought should be added to make it relevant to them.

1343.12.text: And to summarise that project, the young people, I did a thematic analysis, and young people...

1352.04.text: there were four main themes that came out of that – participants could tell that they were different,

1358.14.text: and the ways in which the young people could tell they were different was by challenging gender role expectations.

1364.02.text:
Another way was coming out – that was something
that their heterosexual peers didn’t experience.

1371.00.text:
And this is just a quote from what a young
person said now, who was... not her real name,

1375.01.text:
who was seventeen – she said ‘I came out
and I lost my teens years because I had to

1379.00.text:
grow up, I had to get a job and find my own
place to live and support myself’.

1383.52.text:
That’s not the sort of thing that the average straight
young person has to experience or go through,

1389.70.text:
and it shouldn’t be something we should
have to go through but it is an issue.

1397.37.text: A quote from Raz, who’s... again, not his real name, sixteen, said ‘I lived there for a year’ –

1402.45.text:
this is in reference to the South Island – ‘and that’s when
I went through my depression.

1406.09.text: I faced everything like beatings, discrimination,

1408.93.text: not even being able to get work because of who I was’.

1416.72.text: My favourite from the focus groups was when... favourite in terms of how it stood out,

1421.73.text: was a young woman talking about how some guy had asked her out and then she said, ‘well I’m not interested’

1428.79.text: and then as she’s recounting this conversation, and then he said, ‘well, why not?’,

1433.35.text: and she said, 'well, I'm not interested,' and then he kept pursuing this and said ‘why not?’

1438.00.text: and she said ‘well I’m not into guys’ like this, you know, she was forced into a bit of a corner there,

1442.07.text: well she felt that way I think, and then he said ‘what, you’re a lesbian’ like this,

1446.14.text: and she sort of responded ‘well yes I am’ like this,

1449.60.text: and he said ‘you can’t be a lesbian’.

1451.66.text: It's this classic example of heterosexism, you know,

1454.50.text: you know this very persistent young man who wasn’t going to take any...

1460.31.text: no for an answer and clearly was very heterosexist.

1464.88.text: There was environments and their impact in relation to

1471.06.text: The ways in which participants coped. And I think this is very relevant for what we’re talking about today

1476.87.text: in terms of friends and their value, and the protective strength of that,

1482.81.text: and also the need for hopeful messages.

1486.20.text: So when we’re talking about GLBTTI young people it’s very important to maintain and instil that aspect of hope.

1496.21.text: Depression and sexuality – young people talked about how difficult it was to get help

1502.18.text: and also to get culturally appropriate help.

1508.26.text: So that encouraged me to work with the computer games development company

1514.13.text: Metia Interactive that developed SPARX, to create SPARX: The Rainbow Version.

1519.59.text: And there's just a couple of images from the programme.

1526.23.text: In a nutshell, I conducted an open trial.

1528.87.text: Also we had... the comparison was a larger randomised controlled trial

1535.03.text: with young people recruited from GP surgeries and secondary schools,

1540.47.text: and we asked the students from the main study, or the larger randomised controlled trial

1545.25.text:
about their sexual attraction so we could
actually identify which young people were

1549.00.text:
exclusively opposite sex attracted so I could
compare those two studies.

1554.58.text: But for the open trial, twenty-one young people had depressive symptoms at baseline

1560.40.text: and identified as being same-sex attracted, both sex attracted, or not sure.

1566.13.text: About ninety-one percent completed the intervention,

1569.41.text: and eighty-one percent completed the three month follow-up,

1572.61.text: and that’s just a flow-chart of that there.

1574.86.text: And in a nutshell, sexual minority youth, or those that were

1578.66.text:
attracted to the same sex, both sexes, or
not sure of their sexual attractions

1582.24.text:
were more likely to complete treatment, and that’s
in comparison to

1585.63.text: the larger randomised controlled trial, and the exclusively opposite sex attracted young people from that.

1592.00.text: Eighty-five percent thought that the treatment would appeal to other young people.

1598.04.text: Their depressive symptoms decreased significantly from pre to post-intervention with a...

1603.94.text: what we call a large pre to post-effect size which is clinically meaningful.

1608.85.text: And that positive change was maintained at follow-up.

1613.42.text:
And I’ve got a few quotes as well, this
is from the qualitative evaluation.

1617.37.text:
I asked, ‘Do you think that Rainbow SPARX helped
you feel better?’

1620.94.text: And Troy who’s... not his real name... sixteen said ‘yes, it made me feel a lot better,

1625.08.text: I’ve been much happier because I was able to relate

1627.04.text: and use the information that I learnt to better my situation’.

1631.75.text:
I like this one – Lara says ‘not really,
but it did give me something to do at night

1636.01.text:
so it kind of helped.’
[Audience laughter]

1638.50.text: You know, sort of like keeping you busy, you know, that’s good.

1643.48.text: And then Bob, who was my youngest participant, said ‘it worked for me’.

1649.86.text: And the second project is one that Tommy will know well,

1654.38.text: and Jamie Burford and Priscilla Penniket from Rainbow Youth also know well,

1660.78.text: this was a project that we worked on last year

1663.84.text: evaluating Rainbow Youth’s education package in secondary schools.

1668.10.text:
This is an education package that has two one-hour
workshops – a one-hour workshop on sexuality

1673.40.text: and a one-hour workshop on gender diversity.

1676.42.text: And what was, I guess, an interesting challenge was to conduct these workshops

1683.28.text: and evaluate them with Year 9 and 10 students,

1686.59.text: because bullying is worse with the younger students.

1691.06.text: Mostly the workshops are done with the older students, Year 11 and 12 and 13,

1696.16.text: and we were very keen to see what impact it would have with the younger students.

1701.42.text: 237 students from two secondary schools participated,

1706.38.text: and Jamie led the part of the study that was qualitative, and, again,

1713.00.text: just giving you the nutshell results – school climates were perceived to be hard,

1718.77.text: and bullying or mocking for LGBTTI students,

1723.04.text: and three-quarters of the workshops would reduce bullying.

1727.66.text:
That’s the quantitative result there that I led,
and, yeah,

1733.26.text: very well received with high satisfaction ratings as well.

1745.24.text:
Audience member: That SPARX programme, is that a
local online programme?

1751.96.text: Dr Lucassen: Not available at the moment, but we’re working on that.

1756.59.text: We had the funding from... for the broader SPARX project,

1761.38.text: we had funding for development and evaluation, and not for roll-out.

1766.85.text: It’s a bit more challenging than we thought in terms of getting the funding for the roll-out.

1771.83.text: Understandably we got the funding for development and evaluation because

1775.66.text: no one really wants to pay for it... for a roll-out if it’s...

1779.05.text: if all young people hate it and it doesn’t work, so that’s why it sort of has gone in those phases.

1783.05.text: But that is definitely on the to-do list for 2013.

1791.66.text: Audience: Yeah, hi there Mathijs, I’m just wondering is there any,

1795.89.text: or have you done any research or study on youth suicide

1799.70.text: for youth who have same-sex parents versus heterosexual parents?

1804.74.text: Dr Lucassen: No, no. The stuff that I’ve done has been just about

1812.62.text: and then a secondary analysis based on the students around sexual attraction.

1817.22.text: So not... don’t know in terms of those with parents.

1820.70.text:
But the little that I do know about that field, I believe that
the thinking is

1828.08.text: having parents who are a same-sex couple are "better" than heterosexual couples in many ways.

1837.48.text: I don’t know if it’s for... in relation to suicide.

1850.27.text: Audience member: Do you know if there’s any development on something like SPARX

1854.33.text: for the older... for older age groups?

1857.70.text: Dr Lucassen: Well there are other computerised therapy programmes.

1861.12.text: This is... SPARX is a youth-based programme.

1866.46.text: There’s Beating the Blues which is a British programme

1869.97.text: and I believe that can be accessed through several GPs in... around New Zealand.

1877.67.text: So, actually, in terms of computerised therapy,

1880.78.text: young people are usually the neglected population and there is more in terms of adults.

1885.92.text: What I think is...  would be the case though in New Zealand

1889.71.text: is that we won’t have so many different resources as... that have been developed

1897.03.text: specifically for the New Zealand population,

1898.82.text: but of course the one that stands out would be The Journal

1901.37.text: which is the one with J K and that campaign and therapeutic programme.

1915.30.text: But not specific to sexuality. Yeah.

1922.27.text: Audience member: Hi, the study that was done on the Year 9 and 10 students,

1927.02.text: do we know what the decile rating of the schools were?

1931.35.text:
Dr Lucassen: The decile rating?
For which, sorry? The decile ratings where?

1939.34.text: Audience member: For that seven, yeah.

1940.55.text: Dr Lucassen: Yeah, well they... I don’t know all of them off the top of my head,

1944.51.text: but it’s a cross-section of deciles across the whole of the country,

1949.07.text: so we’ll have a spread of deciles.

1952.37.text: So not just low deciles, not just high deciles,

1954.98.text: but deliberately trying to capture the full range of schools in New Zealand. Yeah.

1962.21.text: Audience member: I understood that the statement was that it was two schools.

1967.13.text: Dr Lucassen: Oh, sorry, the Rainbow Youth education package? Sorry...

1970.83.text: Dr Lucassen: ...I thought you meant Youth ’07. Sorry, I didn’t get that question right.

1973.24.text: No, no, no, that wasn’t the full range of decile ratings, no.

1975.84.text: Dr Lucassen: They were two lower decile rating schools.

1978.46.text: Audience member: They were the lower ones. So... So then the ethnicity would have been?

1982.56.text: Dr Lucassen: Predominantly not New Zealand European.

1992.78.text: Audience member: I was wondering with the Youth ’07 project,

1994.77.text: did you collect any information on the impact of social media, or the digital environment?

2002.56.text:
Dr Lucassen: There are questions around social
media, digital environment, cyber-bullying,

2008.04.text: those sorts of things. That is in the survey more generally.

2014.75.text: The tricky thing around the stuff around sexuality is that we’re already starting with a really small group,

2022.49.text: so there’s always those tensions between, you know, you’ve got a smaller group to start with

2028.08.text: and then when you start looking at the sort of finer details

2031.10.text: you don’t really have the numbers to sustain further analysis.

2034.73.text: But, yeah, there are questions about it in Youth... all of those Youth 2000 surveys, yeah, on that topic.

2046.83.text: Audience: So the people in those youth groups where there was higher rates of suicide,

2052.11.text: suicidal ideation, then the people who.. the ones who hadn’t,

2057.45.text: were they studied in terms of what their resilience and protective factors were?

2063.71.text: Dr Lucassen: Because it’s a cross-sectional survey, so it doesn’t do anything over time,

2067.90.text: we just have a snapshot in time,

2072.46.text: you can start looking at what’s called the sort of mediating, or moderating, factors.

2080.05.text: And I did start doing that, but technically it gets quite untidy,

2086.26.text: and I think that it’s one of the challenges in this field,

2091.33.text: is having small numbers to be able to do quite sort of sophisticated analyses.

2099.83.text: You... I think if you go down that path, the challenge is that you can

2104.70.text: sort of get ripped to shreds scientifically in terms of what you’ve done.

2109.33.text: So really the results might indicate something,

2113.86.text: but there’s not enough substance to the numbers to basically make a compelling case.

2123.77.text: Audience member: Yes. It’s sad that...

2126.87.text: Audience member: ... that if there are people who aren't...

2133.01.text: Audience member: With all those studies with youth,

2136.93.text: was parental permission required for them to participate,

2141.85.text: and do you think that that may in some ways skew the results favourably?

2147.51.text: Dr Lucassen: Is this consent for the Youth ’07 survey, or...?

2152.88.text: Audience member: Well, all those where you’d be looking at people under sixteen.

2157.26.text: Dr Lucassen: Oh I have a... well Mark will know this story well, and Tommy too.

2162.08.text:
I had... well, probably not a paddy with the Ethics
Committee when I was doing...

2167.08.text:
trying to get my ethics application in for the open trial
for Rainbow SPARX,

2172.26.text: and having worked clinically I said to them,

2174.62.text: well, I don’t think you need to disclose to the parents that their young person,

2180.73.text: or their child, is same sex attracted, both sex attracted, questioning their sexuality.

2185.88.text:
They can have all the other information but
I don’t want to give them that information.

2189.54.text: I think the parents will want to know all that information

2193.18.text: but I don’t feel comfortable with the young person having to be "out" to their parents,

2197.91.text: or "outing themselves" by participating in this study.

2200.98.text: And that’s where we sort of had a disagreement, and the Ethics Committee I guess...

2206.02.text: you know, well they’re the Ethics Committee so they said ‘well we’re not going to let you do that’,

2209.09.text: so for a period of time, only sixteen to nineteen year olds could participate in the trial

2217.04.text: because they didn’t need parental consent.

2219.33.text:
But after a period of time, young people approached
me and said that they could get parental consent,

2225.01.text:
so the young people that I’ve got that are
thirteen, fourteen and fifteen years old

2228.09.text:
all had parental consent, and that did involve
their parents being explicitly aware of the

2234.03.text:
young person’s sexuality – which is great,
and was, I think, a leap forward

2238.67.text: in terms of my own thinking and in terms of parents that would be supportive,

2242.74.text: but of course completely means that I think the younger group for that open trial

2249.27.text: is a group that were already quite comfortable with their sexuality and had quite supportive families.

2257.79.text: Audience member: Hi there, my question is about your intervention.

2262.10.text: Is, you are more focused on like a school or individual,

2266.79.text: but for us as minority, I’m a Korean, or thinking of  Māori as well,

2272.18.text: we have a similar cultural, you know, heritage, and for me,

2277.25.text: I’m working with more like a family based.

2280.73.text: If you educate very well with the school or any other organisations,

2285.62.text: but the success rates for helping the gay, or LGBTTI people,

2294.44.text: that I’m thinking is more approach... a proper or appropriate is family-based,

2299.97.text: or like Māori people kaumātua, or like a Korean church leaders based,

2305.90.text: if you educate them, that’s the most important help to our minority people.

2312.54.text: Audience: Yeah. So is the more biggest impact is from family, from churches,

2317.94.text: so how do you think an intervention go to some different dimension?

2323.54.text: Dr Lucassen: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Oh no, I’m completely... I’m smiling just because

2326.15.text: as I was doing the SPARX project, my friend and colleague, Dr Matt Shepherd was...

2332.66.text: who’s Māori and doing his doctorate in clinical psychology,

2336.10.text: conducted a sort of a similar study with Māori young people.

2340.63.text:
And one of the big key findings for him was this sort
of form of therapy is very individualised,

2347.03.text:
and he’s looking at ways in which to support
the programme with whānau,

2353.63.text: making it so that the family gets involved

2357.22.text: and it’s more of a sort of collective focus in terms of intervention.

2361.64.text: I guess my challenge is that for lots of young people, GLBTTI young people,

2368.07.text: their families aren’t really a source of strength,

2372.54.text: they're a source of stress and tension, and so it isn’t...

2376.84.text:
I agree with you in terms of education,
and advocating for improvements,

2383.73.text: but on an individual level I think it varies a lot from young person to young person.

2389.06.text: Some young people have fantastic supportive families,

2392.26.text: a chunk have got families that are quite ambivalent,

2395.09.text:
and then another chunk have got families that
can be quite toxic,

2400.06.text: so that is... yeah, that’s a challenge in the field.

2407.56.text: Audience member: Talofa. My name is Phylesha. I identify as fa’afafine from Samoa, fakafifine from Niue,

2416.08.text: I also have connections with fakaleiti from Tonga, and akava'ine from the Cook Islands.

2421.89.text: You touched briefly on the fact that that disconnection from culture

2428.33.text: sort of was higher risk for these young individuals

2432.33.text: that were disconnected from culture in terms of suicide.

2436.63.text:
My issue is around the terminology,
do you find this a barrier in understanding

2440.47.text:
the cultural stuff when going out there and
researching, or trying to find information?

2445.93.text:
I mean is this a barrier, because I feel that
on the cold face I’m fronted with

2450.04.text:
a lot of individuals who are told... 
Pacific individuals who are told

2453.90.text: that it’s ok to be identifying as lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgendered,

2459.14.text: when in fact when they’re going home and they’re told otherwise:

2462.73.text: what is a lesbian?, what is gay?, what is transgender?

2465.40.text:
We don’t understand that, I’m... you’re fa’afafine. I mean
do you find those types of things?

2471.07.text: In terms of cultural context do you find it a barrier?

2473.78.text: Because I really don’t hear it in the terminology or in any of the findings

2477.26.text: but I know we are huge population in this country.

2480.42.text:
Dr Lucassen: Yeah. Oh no, completely.
I think it’s quite... one of the things that I...

2490.17.text: yeah, I mean it’s so complex, and I guess the thing is when you’re doing stuff...

2496.24.text: and I’ve done a lot of stuff that’s been more quantitative,

2499.10.text: then you have... you’re sort of forced with numbers to work in categories and that is quite limiting.

2507.80.text: And I think it’s an area that you can get people in, say, youth mental health

2515.32.text: who will have a lot of the sort of cultural knowledge and cultural understandings,

2519.75.text: but it’s rare to get the sort of combination of all sorts of those different aspects in one sort of...

2528.98.text: in one person, and so I acknowledge some of my own, perhaps, research limitations,

2536.46.text: but I would also like to say that I keep trying my best to do better,

2541.71.text: so one of the things is around consultation, but the other is just thinking

2546.94.text: how are each of these things stepping stones?

2549.62.text: And so I think we won’t ever in one study address lots of different aspects or components,

2559.45.text: but through a combination and with building blocks I think we can move forward. Yeah.

2567.25.text: Probably a... not necessarily a straightforward answer but also not a straightforward question,

2572.09.text: a complex field really: how the intersection between culture, ethnicity, sexuality, gender,

2579.29.text: how that’s conceptualised it’s so... it can be so different.

2583.88.text: And where one begins and one ends, because people will have different

2592.12.text: Audience: I just really, really noticed the difference in New Zealand rates of suicide

2598.89.text: even just in general, and the other countries.

2602.73.text: Has it sort of been identified what it is exactly that has us leaning

2608.62.text: so far above other countries in the OECD?

2612.75.text: And is some of that a factor of our sort of societal kiwi cultures?

2621.51.text: One of the thing I noticed as a young gay person was I had supportive friends, and my parents weren't too bad,

2629.81.text: but there was still very much a feeling of: if I want to look at a book in the library

2635.36.text: and type the word 'lesbian' in a computer, who's watching?

2639.08.text: Because... and that was more a view of the messages that were coming from society that it's not all okay.

2645.40.text: Dr Lucassen: Yeah, it’s hard, this is... when we get the data you can come up with hypotheses really,

2651.57.text: and it could be a range of different things.

2655.81.text: It could be that we have higher rates with younger people,

2659.53.text: but proportionality lower rates further along the lifespan.

2664.36.text: It could be... yeah, I don’t... the short answer is I actually don’t know,

2670.29.text: and I don’t think anyone really knows categorically,

2674.09.text: we just have different hypotheses as to why that would be,

2678.93.text: and it’s curious because it’s other English language countries, other English language...

2684.09.text: other countries that speak predominantly English have much lower rates

2688.29.text: so it’s sort of why are we that different, so it’s hard to know.
